body:
Thanks for your detailed bug report.

This happens because of the async closing of the file - see the `test: WriteFileHandle.Release OK` after the directory read.

I'll try to think of a way to fix this.

Ideally I'd kill off the async file close, but I haven't figured out how to do that with FUSE.

Note that it will probably work if you do this (ie don't use a 0 length file)

    echo "hello" > mnt/test ; rm mnt/test

I have tested the scenario you suggested, although it wouldn't fix my use case anyway. It produced some very interesting problems, different from what I reported originally. This test was performed on Amazon Drive. I had to repeat the test procedure few times, in most cases it worked, sometimes failed like this:

    $ echo "hello" > mnt/test ; rm mnt/test
    rm: cannot remove 'mnt/test': No such file or directory
    $ ls mnt/test
    512 mnt/test
    $ cat mnt/test
    cat: mnt/test: Input/output error
    $ ls mnt/
    ### Listing of the directory, NOT including the "test" file

Here are the logs from rclone:
```
2017/03/09 09:39:42 DEBUG : test: Dir.Lookup
2017/03/09 09:39:42 DEBUG : test: Dir.Create
2017/03/09 09:39:42 DEBUG : test: Dir.Create OK
2017/03/09 09:39:42 DEBUG : File.Attr valid=1m0s ino=0 size=0 mode=-rw-r--r--
2017/03/09 09:39:42 DEBUG : test: WriteFileHandle.Flush
2017/03/09 09:39:42 DEBUG : test: WriteFileHandle.Flush ignoring flush on unwritten handle
2017/03/09 09:39:42 DEBUG : test: WriteFileHandle.Write len=6
2017/03/09 09:39:43 DEBUG : test: WriteFileHandle.Write OK (6 bytes written)
2017/03/09 09:39:43 DEBUG : test: WriteFileHandle.Flush
2017/03/09 09:39:43 DEBUG : test: Error detected after finished upload - waiting to see if object was uploaded correctly: HTTP code 504: "504 GATEWAY_TIMEOUT": no response body ("504 GATEWAY_TIMEOUT")
2017/03/09 09:39:43 DEBUG : test: Giving up waiting for object - returning original error: HTTP code 504: "504 GATEWAY_TIMEOUT": no response body ("504 GATEWAY_TIMEOUT")
2017/03/09 09:39:43 DEBUG : pacer: Rate limited, sleeping for 947.77941ms (1 consecutive low level retries)
2017/03/09 09:39:43 DEBUG : pacer: low level retry 1/1 (error HTTP code 504: "504 GATEWAY_TIMEOUT": no response body)
2017/03/09 09:39:43 ERROR : test: WriteFileHandle.Flush error: HTTP code 504: "504 GATEWAY_TIMEOUT": no response body
2017/03/09 09:39:43 DEBUG : test: WriteFileHandle.Release nothing to do
2017/03/09 09:39:43 DEBUG : File.Attr valid=1m0s ino=0 size=6 mode=-rw-r--r--
2017/03/09 09:39:43 DEBUG : test: Dir.Remove
2017/03/09 09:39:43 ERROR : test: Dir.Remove error: no such file or directory
```

The situation is worse than in case of empty file. In the case of empty file, first removal failed due to race condition. But after few seconds the file could be opened properly and removed without errors.
In this case when race happens for non-empty file, initial remove fails but then any subsequent attempt for opening or removing the file fails too. The only way to fix it is to unmount and mount again.
@rafal-krypa that is Amazon being unreliable and rclone not retrying the upload (because in the general case it needs to buffer it to disk).    The unreliability I'm going to fix in #711.

issue.title: allow modTime to be changed even before all writers are closed (fixes #1197 -- again)

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
This is "proposal 3" from my [previous comment](https://github.com/ncw/rclone/issues/1197#issuecomment-289964080). I decided not to hand down error until there's an actual bug reported that warrants complicating the error handling in `WriteFileHandle.close`. 

It fixes not only the `cp -a` issue, but also the stale cache issue that would result in the dir listing showing a wrong timestamp for some time directly after copying. 

Cheers
Stefan

issue.title: can't rsync 0-byte file to mount

milestone.title: Known Problem
milestone.description: This milestone contains issues which are known problems which are proving difficult to fix, or are awaiting an external fix or we haven't got round to yet.

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
encrypted mount on gdrive. trying to rsync a 0 byte file onto the mount breaks rsync.

I'm guessing that because you don't flush unwritten handles, it doesn't update the directory cache before the rename?  This wouldn't be a problem except for a file that didn't previously exist.  Of course I'm guessing without looking at code, so who knows.

here's everything:
```
bittaurus@bugs ~ $ uname -a
Linux bugs.are.everywhere 4.9.20-hardened-bugs-r1 #2 SMP Sun Apr 9 10:02:56 2017 x86_64 Intel(R) Pentium(R) CPU G850 @ 2.90GHz GenuineIntel GNU/Linux

bittaurus@bugs ~ $ rsync --version
rsync  version 3.1.2  protocol version 31
Copyright (C) 1996-2015 by Andrew Tridgell, Wayne Davison, and others.
Web site: http://rsync.samba.org/
Capabilities:
    64-bit files, 64-bit inums, 64-bit timestamps, 64-bit long ints,
    socketpairs, hardlinks, symlinks, IPv6, batchfiles, inplace,
    append, ACLs, xattrs, iconv, symtimes, prealloc

bittaurus@bugs ~ $ rclone --version
rclone v1.37-093-gb510c70cβ
- os/arch: linux/amd64
- go version: go1.8.3

bittaurus@bugs ~ $ rsync -a /home/bittaurus/0bytes /home/bittaurus/w
rsync: rename "/home/bittaurus/w/.0bytes.4toVlh" -> "0bytes": No such file or directory (2)
rsync error: some files/attrs were not transferred (see previous errors) (code 23) at main.c(1178) [sender=3.1.2]

bittaurus@bugs ~ $ rclone -vv mount b:Downloads ~/w
2017/08/13 18:31:35 DEBUG : rclone: Version "v1.37-093-gb510c70cβ" starting with parameters ["rclone" "-vv" "mount" "b:Downloads" "/home/bittaurus/w"]
2017/08/13 18:31:37 INFO  : Encrypted drive 'b:Downloads': Modify window is 1ms
2017/08/13 18:31:37 DEBUG : Encrypted drive 'b:Downloads': Mounting on "/home/bittaurus/w"
2017/08/13 18:31:37 mount helper error: fusermount: failed to open /etc/mtab: Permission denied
2017/08/13 18:31:37 DEBUG : : Root:
2017/08/13 18:31:37 DEBUG : : >Root: node=/, err=<nil>
2017/08/13 18:31:54 DEBUG : /: Attr:
2017/08/13 18:31:54 DEBUG : /: >Attr: attr=valid=1m0s ino=0 size=0 mode=drwxr-xr-x, err=<nil>
2017/08/13 18:32:37 DEBUG : /: Lookup: name="0bytes"
2017/08/13 18:32:38 DEBUG : /: >Lookup: node=<nil>, err=no such file or directory
2017/08/13 18:32:38 DEBUG : /: Lookup: name="0bytes"

2017/08/13 18:32:38 DEBUG : /: Lookup: name=".0bytes.4toVlh"
2017/08/13 18:32:38 DEBUG : /: >Lookup: node=<nil>, err=no such file or directory

2017/08/13 18:32:38 DEBUG : /: >Create: node=.0bytes.4toVlh, handle=.0bytes.4toVlh (w), err=<nil>
2017/08/13 18:32:38 DEBUG : .0bytes.4toVlh: Attr:
2017/08/13 18:32:38 DEBUG : .0bytes.4toVlh: >Attr: a=valid=1m0s ino=0 size=0 mode=-rw-r--r--, err=<nil>
2017/08/13 18:32:38 DEBUG : .0bytes.4toVlh: Setattr: a=Setattr [ID=0x9 Node=0x2 Uid=1070 Gid=1070 Pid=64072] mode=-rw------- handle=INVALID-0x0
2017/08/13 18:32:38 DEBUG : .0bytes.4toVlh: >Setattr: err=<nil>

2017/08/13 18:32:38 DEBUG : .0bytes.4toVlh (w): >Flush: err=<nil>

2017/08/13 18:32:38 DEBUG : .0bytes.4toVlh: WriteFileHandle.Release closing

2017/08/13 18:32:38 DEBUG : /: >Remove: err=no such file or directory
2017/08/13 18:32:40 DEBUG : .0bytes.4toVlh: File.applyPendingModTime OK
2017/08/13 18:32:40 DEBUG : .0bytes.4toVlh (w): >Release: err=<nil>
```

body:
I looked into a synchronous `release`, but as far as I can tell the best approach was a patchset from around 2014 that introduced this feature – it didn't get merged into the kernel, so, no dice.

Here's another idea: create a 0 byte file when trying to flush an unwritten handle. Only once of course, unless a write happens – which then would behave like it does not and possibly overwrite a file of the same name. Obvious downside is the extra request even when not needed (for sure when using a pipe, possibly other cases). It would also most likely fix `rsync`, for better or worse.

issue.title: rclone mount: race condition with multiple RWFileHandle's

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
Following the forum thread [Extracting to ACD mount possible?](https://forum.rclone.org/t/extracting-to-acd-mount-possible/4161) I'm now creating this issue.

I found a race condition involving multiple open `*vfs.RWFileHandle`'s for one file.

This is a log containing a failed upload: [rclone_extract_ptr_empty.log](https://gist.github.com/B4dM4n/2aecfd06a48d2099df768ec46af69889#file-rclone_extract_ptr_empty-log). The state after this log is the following:
- Test/JD/rand4/rand.bin size=0 mtime=2018-01-29 21:25:18.826 +0100 (mtime of the source)
- Test/JD/rand4/rand.bin size=0 mtime=2018-01-30 14:46:04.??? +0100 (mtime of upload time)

I assume the problem is `*vfs.RWFileHandle.close()` not being synchronized between multiple files.
The log file above shows two `close()` executing in parallel.

The first `RWFileHandle` belongs to a new empty file. The second one the handle being written to. During the `close()` of the first handle, the empty cache file gets `Move`'ed to the backend. After the move is completed the cache file get's deleted.
When the second `close()` tries to move the cache file, which is already gone.

This could also be related to #1181.

I think, `close()` should check whether there is another `RWFileHandle` opened for it's file. Hopefully this fixes the race condition.


> What is your rclone version (eg output from `rclone -V`)

rclone v1.39-096-gcf6d522d
> Which OS you are using and how many bits (eg Windows 7, 64 bit)

Linux 4.14.13-1-ARCH #1 SMP PREEMPT Wed Jan 10 11:14:50 UTC 2018 x86_64 GNU/Linux
> Which cloud storage system are you using? (eg Google Drive)

Google Drive
> The command you were trying to run (eg `rclone copy /tmp remote:tmp`)

`rclone mount -vv --dir-cache-time 24h --vfs-cache-mode writes TestDrive:Test/JD /mnt/JD/extracted`
